facts.text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) purports to create an additional civil court for Greater Bombay having jurisdiction to try suits and other proceedings of a civil nature not exceeding a certain value.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act purports to create an additional civil companyrt for Greater Bombay having jurisdiction to try, receive and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature number exceeding a certain value, subject to certain exceptions which need number be referred to here.

facts.text: The first respondent brought a suit in the High Court at Bombay on its original side for recovery of Rs. 11,704 from the second respondent on promissory notes.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent brought the suit in the High Court at Bombay on its original side for recovery of Rs. 11,704 from the second respondent on promissory numberes.

facts.text: The first respondent presented a plaint to the Prothonotary and Senior Master of the High Court on the 6th February, 1950 for filing a summary suit against the second respondent to recover Rs. 11,704-2-4 under promissory notes.

anchor.surface_text: on the 6th February, 1950, the first respondent presented a plaint to the Prothonotary and Senior Master of the High Court for filing a summary suit against the second respondent to recover a sum of Rs. 11,704-2-4 alleged to be due under promissory numbere.

facts.text: A notification dated the 20th January, 1950 was issued under Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act enhancing the pecuniary limit to Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: in companytravention of a numberification dated the 20th January, 1950, issued under Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, under which suits up to the pecuniary limit of Rs. 25,000 companyld be heard only by the City Civil Court

facts.text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 came into force on 10th May, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Bombay Act of 1948 came into force on 10th May, 1948.

facts.text: On 23rd February, 1950, the learned Judge admitted the plaint holding that Section 4 of the Act was ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: On 23rd February, 1950, the learned Judge admitted the plaint holding that Section 4 of the Act was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature and the numberification issued under it was companysequently inoperative

facts.text: The High Court judgment is dated the 29th March, 1950, in Suit No. 240 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay dated the 29th March, 1950, in Suit No. 240 of 1950,

facts.text: The High Court held that the Act was intra vires but Section 4 was void as delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court  Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.  held  1  the Act was intra vires, but  2  that Section 4 which authorised the Provincial Government to enhance the jurisdiction of the City Court up the limit of Rs. 25,000 amounted to a delegation of legislative power,

facts.text: Section 3 of the Act provides that the City Civil Court shall have jurisdiction to receive, try and dispose of all suits of civil nature not exceeding Rs. 10,000 arising within Greater Bombay, subject to exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything companytained in any law, such companyrt shall have jurisdiction to receive, try and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature number exceeding ten thousand rupees in value, and arising within the Greater Bombay, except suits or proceedings which are companynisable -

facts.text: Section 4 of the Act authorizes the Provincial Government by notification to invest the City Civil Court with jurisdiction up to Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the exceptions specified in Section 3 the State Government may by numberification in the Official Gazette, invest the City Court with jurisdiction to receive, try and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature arising within the Greater Bombay and of such value number exceeding twenty-five thousand rupees

facts.text: Section 12 of the Act bars the High Court from trying suits cognizable by the City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything companytained in any law, the High Court shall number have jurisdiction to try suits and proceedings companynisable by the City Court

facts.text: The suit value exceeds Rs. 10,000 but not Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: the suit, which exceeded Rs. 10,000 in value and was number companynisable by the City Court apart from the impeached numberification,

facts.text: Promissory notes are mentioned in entry 28 of List I of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: such as, for instance, promissory numberes, which is one of the subjects mentioned in entry 28 of List I .

facts.text: The State of Bombay was made a party defendant on its own motion due to constitutional issues.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the companystitutional issues thus raised, the State of Bombay, the appellant herein was on its own motion, made a party defendant.

facts.text: The Division Bench of the High Court upheld the view that Section 4 is void.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench upheld the view of the Judge in Chambers and returned the cause to him for disposal on the merits.

facts.text: The appeal to this Court challenges both findings of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Both these findings have been challenged before us as erroneous, the first by the first respondent and the second by the appellant.

facts.text: The High Court relied on its earlier decision in Mulchand v. Raman 51 B.L.R. 86 to hold the Act intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: On the first question the High Court placed reliance on its own earlier decision in Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.B. 86., and held that the Act was intra vires the Bombay Legislature.

facts.text: The State of Bombay preferred the present appeal dissatisfied with the High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay, dissatisfied with this decision, has preferred the present appeal.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. generally agrees with Mahajan J.'s judgment.

arguments.claim: The Act is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay because it confers jurisdiction on the new court not only in respect of matters in List II but also List I matters like promissory notes.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the respondents that the Act is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay, because it confers jurisdiction on the new court not only in respect of matters which the Provincial Legislature is competent to legislate upon under List II of the 7th Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, but also in regard to matters in respect of which only the Central or Federal Legislature can legislate under List I such as, for instance, promissory notes,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: al Court, with respect to any of the matters in this List. The respondents companytention may appear at the first sight to be a plausible one, but, in

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 1 List II includes general jurisdiction over all civil matters; special entries allow barring or special jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Entry 53 List I, entries 1 and 2 List II, entry 15 List III limit provincial jurisdiction to List II matters only.

anchor.surface_text: To understand this argument, it is necessary to refer to entry 53 of List I, entries 1 and 2 of List II and also entry 15 of List III. These entries run as follows - Entry 53, List I - Jurisdiction and powers of all courts except the Federal Court, with respect to any of the matters in this List

arguments.court_reasoning: Entry 1 List II is general power including jurisdiction; others are special powers.

arguments.claim: Administration of justice in entry 1 List II includes jurisdiction and powers of courts as it is wide enough.

anchor.surface_text: A reference to three Legislative Lists shows that a administration of justice is entirely a provincial subject on which only the Provincial Legislature can legislate. The same remark applies to constitution and organization of all courts except the Federal Court.

arguments.claim: Entry 2 List II and entry 53 List I confer special powers supplementary to general power in entry 1 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to the exact meaning of entry 2 of List II and entry 53 of List I, which are said to militate against the above construction. These entries, in my opinion, confer special powers on Provincial and Central Legislatures, as opposed to the general power conferred on the Provincial Legislature by entry 1 of List II,

arguments.claim: Section 9 CPC supports that legislatures can bar general jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, reference may be made to Section 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, which provides that - the Courts shall have jurisdiction to try all suits of a civil nature excepting suits of which their cognizance is either expressly or impliedly barred.

arguments.claim: Respondent's construction leads to anomalous results, e.g., no jurisdiction until specific legislation.

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation which is sought to be put on the entries by the respondent is in my opinion open to the following objections - It involves the curtailment of the meaning of the expression administration of justice in such a way as to rob it of its primary content - the jurisdiction and powers of the court,

arguments.claim: Section 4 is valid conditional legislation, not delegation, as legislature fixed policy and limits.

arguments.claim: Queen v. Burah analogous; S.4 intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In Queen v. Burah 5 I.A. 178, Section 9 of Act XXII of 1869, which was a piece of legislation analogous to Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, was held intra vires by their Lordships of the Privy Council.

arguments.claim: Jatindranath Gupta case distinguishes; no modification or re-enactment here.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in support of its view placed considerable reliance on the decision of the Federal Court in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar 1949 F.C.R. 593 and it was considered that the present case fell within the ambit of the rule therein laid down. It seems to me that the decision in the Bihar case has no application to the case in hand.

arguments.claim: S.3 void as trenches on List I by conferring jurisdiction on all civil suits.

arguments.court_reasoning: Pith and substance administration of justice under List II entry 1.

arguments.claim: Act intra vires under entry 1 List II as administration of justice includes jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the contention of the learned Attorney-General that the Act is intra vires the Bombay Legislature under entry 1 of List II is sound and I am in respectful agreement with the view expressed by the Chief Justice of Bombay on this point in Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.R. 86.

holdings.text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 is intra vires the Provincial Legislature under entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 1 List II confers general power over administration of justice including jurisdiction; special entries (2 List II, 53 List I) supplement for specific matters; pith and substance is provincial; follows Mulchand v. Raman.

holdings.text: Section 4 of the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 is intra vires and constitutes valid conditional legislation, not an invalid delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: in my judgment, the High Court was in error in holding that Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act was void and ultra vires the Provincial Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature fixed policy (initial Rs10k, max Rs25k) and exceptions; executive determines timing via notification; follows Queen v. Burah as conditional legislation; distinguishes Jatindranath Gupta.

holdings.text: The High Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit as it is cognizable by the City Civil Court under Sections 3, 4 and 12 of the Act and the valid notification.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the High Court has no jurisdiction to hear and determine the first respondents suit and I agree that the appeal should be allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.12 bars High Court jurisdiction over suits cognizable by City Court; notification under valid S.4 enhances limit to Rs25k covering suit value; Act valid.

holdings.text: Entry 1 of List II ('administration of justice; constitution and organisation of all courts') includes power to confer general civil jurisdiction on provincial courts.

anchor.surface_text: the words administration of justice constitution and organization of courts in entry 1 of List II, although they might be wide enough, if that entry stood alone, to include the topic of jurisdiction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide language includes jurisdiction necessary for courts to function; entry 2 List II supplements for special jurisdiction re List II matters; legislative practice and harmonious construction; pith and substance doctrine resolves incidental overlap with List I.

holdings.text: The impugned provision in Section 4 is conditional legislation where the legislature has determined policy and outer limits, leaving execution to executive.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned provision is an instance of what the Privy Council has designated as conditional legislation, and does not really delegate any legislative power but merely prescribes as to how effect is to be given to what the Legislature has already decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 3 and 4 read together fix initial and maximum pecuniary jurisdiction; government decides when to extend within limits; precedent of Queen v. Burah.

holdings.text: Provincial courts have general jurisdiction over civil suits including those incidentally touching List I matters like promissory notes, unless expressly barred.

anchor.surface_text: promissory notes, which is one of the subjects mentioned in entry 28 of List I .

holdings.reasoning_summary: General jurisdiction under entry 1 List II; List I entry 53 allows federal legislature to bar or confer special jurisdiction if needed; pre-1935 practice continues; Prafulla Kumar supports pith and substance.

precedents.citation: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee and Other v. Bank of Commerce Limited, Khulnal 1947 F.C.R. 28.

Bank of Commerce Limited, Khulnal 1947 F.C.R. 28., in which the arguments of the respondents before the Privy Council proceeded on the same lines as the arguments of the respondents before us. The question raised in that case was as to the validity of the Bengal Money-lenders Act, 1940,

precedents.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Limited
precedents.cited_proposition: Validity of provincial legislation affecting promissory notes under List I through pith and substance of money-lending

anchor.surface_text: As several of my learned colleagues have pointed out, the case of Queen v. Burah 3 A.C. 889., the authority of which was not questioned before us, fully covers the contention raised, and the impugned provision is an instance of what the Privy Council has designated as conditional legislation, and does not really delegate any legislative power but merely prescribes as to how effect is to be given to what the Legislature has already decided.

precedents.cited_proposition: Conditional legislation does not constitute delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad, the learned Attorney-General who appeared on behalf of the appellant, contended that in this country even delegated legislation is permissible, but I do not consider it necessary to go into that question, because the principle enunciated in Queen v. Burah 5 I.A. 178 is sufficient to dispose of the contention raised here.

precedents.cited_proposition: Principle against delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: As some of the American Judges have remarked, there are many things upon which wise and useful legislation must depend which cannot be known to the law-making power and must therefore be the subject of enquiry and determination outside the halls of legislation  Field v. Clark 143 U.S. 649.

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature can make law conditional on future events without delegating power to make law

anchor.surface_text: I think that the present case stands well outside what was laid down by the Federal Court in Jitendranath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar 1949 F.C.R. 595, as two of my colleagues who were parties to the majority decision in that case have pointed out.

Raman 51 B.L.R. 86, which was followed by the learned Judges in the present case, and the Attorney-General who adopted the same line before us, invoked the doctrine of pith and substance in answer to the argument on behalf of the respondent.

precedents.cited_proposition: Act intra vires under pith and substance

precedents.citation: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.B. 86.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the first respondent strongly relied on that decision and suggested that, if it had been brought to the notice of the learned Judges in Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.B. 86., their decision might well have been the other way.

precedents.case_name: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah
precedents.cited_proposition: Construction of legislative entries regarding jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: A similar difficulty in construing entry 4 of List III and entry 2 of List II arose in Stewart v. Brojendra Kishore and led a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court to construe the expression civil procedure occurring in the former entry in a limited sense as excluding jurisdiction and powers of courts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Civil procedure excludes jurisdiction and powers of courts

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the decision of the Judicial Committee in In re Marriage Reference 1912 A.C. 880 where marriage and divorce in the Dominion List was construed as excluding matters relating to the solemnisation of marriage in the province because the latter topic was specifically included in the Provincial List,

precedents.cited_proposition: Specific entries exclude overlapping in general entries

anchor.surface_text: He placed reliance on the following observations of Gwyer C.J. in Atiqa Begums case 1940 F.C.R. 110, 134. It would be practically impossible for example to define each item in the Provincial List in such a way as to make it exclusive of every item in that List

precedents.cited_proposition: Entries in lists to be read broadly, including ancillary matters

anchor.surface_text: The test for determining whether in pith and substance a particular enactment falls within one list or another is further elucidated in a passage quoted with approval from Lefroys Treatise on Canadian Constitutional Law in the judgment of the Federal Court in the Bank of Commerce case 1944 F.C.R. 126, 139

precedents.cited_proposition: Pith and substance test from Canadian law

anchor.surface_text: That it is legitimate to have regard to legislative practice in determining the scope of legislative powers has been recognised in decisions of high authority  e.g., Croft v. Dunphy  1933 A.C. 156, 165

precedents.cited_proposition: Legitimate to consider legislative practice for scope of powers

anchor.surface_text: wherein referring to Lockes case 72 Pa. 491. the following observations were made - To assert that a law is less than law, because it is made it is made to depend on a future event or act, is to rob the Legislature of the power to act wisely for the public welfare whenever a law is passed relating to a state of affairs not yet developed,

precedents.citation: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.R. 86

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the contention of the learned Attorney-General that the Act is intra vires the Bombay Legislature under entry 1 of List II is sound and I am in respectful agreement with the view expressed by the Chief Justice of Bombay on this point in Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 51 Bom. L.R. 86.

precedents.case_name: Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah
precedents.cited_proposition: Act intra vires under entry 1 List II

anchor.surface_text: In Queen v. Burah 5 I.A. 178, Section 9 of Act XXII of 1869, which was a piece of legislation analogous to Section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, was held intra vires by their Lordships of the Privy Council.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section allowing extension of Act's application is conditional legislation, intra vires

precedents.citation: Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar 1949 F.C.R. 593

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in support of its view placed considerable reliance on the decision of the Federal Court in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar 1949 F.C.R. 593 and it was considered that the present case fell within the ambit of the rule therein laid down.

precedents.case_name: Jatindra Nath Gupta v. Province of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: Invalid delegation where government can modify and extend Act

justification_sets.label: Bombay City Civil Court Act Section 12 support

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 held intra vires; Section 4 held intra vires and not delegation of legislative power; High Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit as it is cognizable by City Civil Court.
directions: Suit not maintainable in High Court

Doctrine rebuts argument that jurisdiction over List I matters makes Act ultra vires by allowing incidental encroachments
Pith and substance doctrine attributes Act to List II (administration of justice), supporting intra vires holding under entry 1 List II
Doctrine confirms pith as administration of justice, supporting holding that entry 1 List II includes power for general civil jurisdiction
Doctrine permits incidental encroachment on List I (e.g., promissory notes), supporting holding of general provincial jurisdiction over civil suits
Doctrine determines true nature and character of Act to address whether it is ultra vires the State Legislature
Doctrine assesses dominant character of jurisdiction provisions to address ultra vires challenge re High Court and City Civil Court powers
